channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Biden Prepares to Take Office, a New Rush at the Border
item.description: The president-elect has promised a more humane border policy. But devastated economies and natural disasters in Latin America have fueled a spike in migration that could make pledges hard to keep.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Francisco Velasquez, a young Guatemalan who lost his home in a hurricane, hoped to work in Florida but was arrested by Border Patrol agents and returned to Mexico.

item.title: Hospitals Prepare for First Shots as Virus Vaccine Shipments Blanket U.S.
item.description: The first of nearly three million doses were sent across the country, the start of the most ambitious vaccination campaign in the nation’s history.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Amy Harmon and Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Morry Gash
item.media:description: Boxes containing the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine were moved to a loading dock for shipping at the Pfizer Global Supply Kalamazoo manufacturing plant Kalamazoo, Mich., on Sunday.

item.title: Young People Have Less Covid-19 Risk, but in College Towns, Deaths Rose Fast
item.description: Links between university outbreaks and deaths in the wider community are often indirect and difficult to document, but some health experts say there are clear signs of a connection.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Ivory, Robert Gebeloff and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ingham County, Mich., which includes Michigan State University, went from reporting about 300 new infections in August to about 1,800 in September.

item.title: A State Scientist Questioned Florida’s Virus Data. Now Her Home’s Been Raided.
item.description: Rebekah Jones became an unlikely celebrity when she lost her job running the state’s coronavirus data dashboard. Police say a breach at the Department of Health was traced to her computer.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Aileen Perilla for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebekah Jones has urged health department employees to denounce what she says has been the manipulation and obfuscation of virus data to make Florida look better off than it really is.

item.title: Schools Will Close in Germany as Cases Surge
item.description: Even in a country once seen as a success story, the second wave is taking a toll on education
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick

item.title: Watch live: Electors to vote in Pennsylvania.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times

item.title: Hearing Aids Could Use Some Help
item.description: The vital medical devices could be inexpensive and available over the counter. But efforts have stalled under the F.D.A.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Isabel Seliger

item.title: Mary Nichols Appears to Be Out of Running to Lead E.P.A.
item.description: The president-elect’s transition team is scrambling to find a new candidate for the E.P.A. after advocates objected to Mary D. Nichols.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mary D. Nichols, head of the California Air Resources Board, with Gov. Gavin Newsom last year.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 2 Iranian Officials in Robert Levinson Case
item.description: The Treasury imposed sanctions on two Interior Ministry officials, who it said were “involved in the abduction, detention and probable death” of Mr. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Christine Levinson, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Robert Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent, disappeared under mysterious circumstances off Iran’s Kish Island in March 2007.

item.title: Young Kim Discusses the California G.O.P., After Trump
item.description: Monday: The representative-elect discusses the state’s pandemic response and the future of the Republican Party: “This is not a Trump or Biden issue.”
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Chris Carlson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Young Kim, who was elected to the 39th Congressional District in California.

item.title: The Electoral College Meets
item.description: An archaic institution finds itself in the spotlight: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: A Big Day in the U.S.
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s attempts to remain in power have exposed vulnerabilities in the Electoral College.

item.title: It’s a Terrible Time for Small Businesses. Except When It’s Not.
item.description: Some entrepreneurs are finding opportunities in unlikely places.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Hannon
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Brendan and Alexi Coffey started their business, Steward, to help people become successful plant growers.

item.title: Can Congress Overturn the Electoral College Results? Probably Not
item.description: Republicans are planning one final showdown. They are almost certain to fail, but not before Vice President Mike Pence is thrust into having to declare President Trump the loser.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congress has a normally perfunctory final say in the election that threatens to become a messy last stand this year.

item.title: What’s Next for Trump Voters Who Believe the Election Was Stolen?
item.description: Some are certain the election was fraudulent. Others aren’t so sure. What becomes of their skepticism has important implications for American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Trump gathered for a rally in Washington on Saturday.

item.title: Conflicting Narratives Emerge in Ohio Shooting, Prompting Protests
item.description: Much about the shooting death of Casey Goodson Jr. by a sheriff’s deputy has been disputed — what led to it, why it happened and where exactly on his body Mr. Goodson was shot.
item.dc:creator: Lucia Walinchus and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Da'Shaunae Marisa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting the death of Casey Goodson Jr. in Columbus, Ohio, on Friday.

item.title: Electoral College Voter: Long an Honor, and Now Also a Headache
item.description: Casting votes in the Electoral College has been a routine part of election mechanics, but this year electors have been thrust into the cross hairs of President Trump’s extraordinary effort to overturn the results.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khary Penebaker, a Wisconsin elector, in Milwaukee. “This is some scary stuff, man,” he said of the extra security required for the Electoral College voters this year.

item.title: Storm May Bring Over 6 Inches of Snow From Virginia to New England
item.description: Some areas north and west of the Interstate 95 corridor in New Jersey and Pennsylvania may get more than a foot of snow on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Justin Lane/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Falling snow as a winter storm hit Manhattan last December. Heavy snow is expected west and north of the I-95 corridor on Wednesday, just days after an unseasonably warm Sunday.

item.title: As U.S. Deaths Approach 300,000, Obituaries Force Reckoning with Covid
item.description: Families of some who perished have written pointedly about the virus in remembrances. They tell of agonizing final days. They plead for wearing of masks.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Lucy Hewett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparations for a funeral at Adolf Funeral Home & Cremation Services in Willowbrook, Ill., on Friday.

item.title: Trump Rescinds Plan for White House Staff to Be Quickly Vaccinated
item.description: The administration had initially defended a plan to distribute vaccines to its senior members even as the first doses are generally being reserved for high-risk health care workers.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: It was not immediately clear why President Trump decided to change the policy, or whether he had even been aware of it ahead of time.

item.title: Russian Hackers Broke Into Federal Agencies, U.S. Officials Suspect
item.description: In one of the most sophisticated and perhaps largest hacks in more than five years, email systems were breached at the Treasury and Commerce Departments. Other breaches are under investigation.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Patrick Semansky/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Treasury Department was one of the agencies targeted by the hackers.

item.title: Trump Administration Plans a Rushed Effort to Encourage Americans to Be Vaccinated
item.description: A large-scale public education campaign, delayed by false starts and investigations, will get off the ground just as the coronavirus vaccine becomes available to high-risk Americans.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Rey Del Rio/Getty Images
item.media:description: Loading shipments of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine onto a UPS plane in Michigan on Sunday. The first vaccinations are expected to be administered on Monday.

item.title: Covid Patient Study Shows Some Benefit From an Arthritis Drug
item.description: Baricitinib had previously attracted some scrutiny from experts, who were unsure when it would most help their patients.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura/Getty Images
item.media:description: Gabriel Cervera Rodriguez, left, and Elizabeth Gamboa, middle, inserted a tube into a patient's chest at the United Memorial Medical Center in Houston.

item.title: 2 Who Escaped in Tennessee Are Caught 2 Days Later in Florida
item.description: Robert Lee Brown and Christopher Osteen escaped from a state prison in Lake County, Tenn., and were tracked down a thousand miles away just off the beach in Broward County, Fla.
item.dc:creator: Marie Fazio and Bryan Pietsch
item.media:credit: Tennessee Bureau of Investigation, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Christopher Osteen, left, and Robert Brown escaped from a prison in Lake County, Tenn., on Friday morning, the authorities said. They were captured on Sunday in South Florida.

item.title: Man Is Arrested in Stabbing at D.C. Election Protest
item.description: The confrontation near the White House between supporters and opponents of President Trump was one of several on Saturday in Washington and in state capitals across the country.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A District of Columbia police officer protected a man who was arrested on Saturday after four members of the far-right Proud Boys were stabbed at a bar after a day of often-violent confrontations.

item.title: The C.D.C. formally approves allowing people 16 and up to receive the vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Morry Gash
item.media:description: Boxes containing the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine are prepared for shipment at a plant in Portage, Mich., on Sunday.
